\[ L(f) = \lim_{p \to \infty} L \left( \sum_{n=1}^{p} f \xi_{F_n} \right) = \lim_{p \to \infty} \sum_{n=1}^{p} L \left( f \xi_{F_n} \right) \]

(20.20) Theorem. Let \((X, \mathcal{A}, \mu)\) be a decomposable measure space (19.25). Then the mapping \(T\) defined by

\[ T(g) = L_{\bar{g}} \]

[see (20.16)] is a norm-preserving linear mapping of \(\mathcal{L}_{\infty}\) onto the conjugate space \(\mathcal{L}_{+}^{*}\). Thus, as Banach spaces, \(\mathcal{L}_{\infty}\) and \(\mathcal{L}_{+}^{*}\) are isomorphic.

Proof. The fact that \(T\) is a norm-preserving mapping from \(\mathcal{L}_{\infty}\) into \(\mathcal{L}_{+}^{*}\) is (20.16). It follows from (20.19) that \(T\) is onto \(\mathcal{L}_{+}^{*}\). It is trivial that \(T\) is linear. Since \(T\) is both linear and norm-preserving, it is one-to-one. \(\square\)

(20.21) Note. As we have shown in (20.17), the conclusion in (20.20) fails for some nondecomposable measure spaces. However J. Schwartz has found a representation of \(\mathcal{L}_{+}^{*}(X, \mathcal{A}, \mu)\) for arbitrary \((X, \mathcal{A}, \mu)\) [Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 2 (1951), 270–275], to which the interested reader is referred.

(20.22) Exercise. Let \(X\) be a locally compact Hausdorff space and let \(\nu\) be an outer measure on \(\mathcal{P}(X)\) as in § 9. Prove that the definitions of local \(\nu\)-nullity given in (9.29) and in (20.11) are equivalent.

(20.23) Exercise. Let \((X, \mathcal{A}, \mu)\) be a degenerate measure space such that \(\mu(X) = \infty\) [see (10.3) for the definition]. Is this measure space decomposable? Find \(\mathcal{L}_{1}, \mathcal{L}_{+}^{*},\) and \(\mathcal{L}_{\infty}\) explicitly for this measure space.

(20.24) Exercise. Let \((X, \mathcal{A}, \mu)\) be any measure space and let \(f \in \mathcal{L}_{1}(X, \mathcal{A}, \mu)\). Define \(L\) on \(\mathcal{L}_{\infty}(X, \mathcal{A}, \mu)\) by

\[ L(g) = \int_{X} g \bar{f} \, d\mu. \]

Prove that \(L \in \mathcal{L}_{\infty}^{*}\) and that \(\|L\| = \|f\|_{1}\).

(20.25) Exercise. Prove that \(\mathcal{L}_{1}([0, 1])\) [with Lebesgue measure] is not reflexive by showing that not every \(L \in \mathcal{L}_{\infty}^{*}([0, 1])\) has the form described in (20.24). [Hint. Use the H. h. Banach theorem to produce an \(L \neq 0\) such that \(L(g) = 0\) for all \(g \in \mathcal{L}_{\infty}\) for which \(g\) is essentially continuous, i.e., \(\|g - h\|_{\infty} = 0\) for some \(h \in \mathcal{C}([0, 1])\).]

(20.26) Exercise. (a) Prove that \(\mathcal{L}_{\infty}([0, 1])\) is not separable.

(b) Find necessary and sufficient conditions on a measure space that its \(\mathcal{L}_{\infty}\) space be separable. [Do not forget (20.23).]
